metadata.section_title: Entry requirements for Visitors

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for Visitors

1.   V 1.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a Visitor must apply for and obtain entry clearance before they arrive in the UK if they are: 
    1.   (a) a visa national, unless V 1.3. (b) applies; or
    2.   (b) seeking to marry or form a civil partnership, or give notice of marriage or civil partnership, in the UK unless they are a “relevant national” as defined in section 62 of the Immigration Act 2014; or
    3.   (c) seeking to come to the UK as a Visitor for more than 6 months.

1.   V 1.2. Within the period for which the entry clearance is valid, a Visitor may enter and leave the UK multiple times, unless the entry clearance is endorsed as single or dual entry.

1.   V 1.3. A person seeking to come to the UK as a Visitor may apply for permission to enter on arrival in the UK where they are: 
    1.   (a) a non-visa national, unless V 1.1. (b) or (c) apply; or
    2.   (b) a visa national and an exception applies as set out in Appendix Visitor: Visa National list or Appendix Visitor: Transit Without Visa Scheme.

1.   V 1.4. A person seeking to enter the UK as a Visitor must, where required, under Appendix Electronic Travel Authorisation, obtain an Electronic Travel Authorisation before travelling to the UK.

1.   V 1.5. A child who holds entry clearance as a Visitor on arrival in the UK must either: 
    1.   (a) hold a valid entry clearance that states they are accompanied and will be travelling with an adult identified on that entry clearance; or
    2.   (b) hold an entry clearance which states they are unaccompanied; otherwise

2.   the child may be refused entry to the UK, unless they meet the requirements of V 5.1. and V 5.2.
chunks.summary: Visitors aiming to enter the UK must generally obtain entry clearance before arrival, especially if they are visa nationals, plan to marry, civil partner, or stay over 6 months. Eligible non-visa nationals can apply on arrival, and some travelers need an Electronic Travel Authorization. Children traveling with visitors must have valid, appropriate entry clearance.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Visitor

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Visitor

1.   V 2.1. A person applying for entry clearance as a Visitor must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form “Apply for a UK visit visa” unless they are applying for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor, in which case they must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form “Apply for an exempt, diplomatic, official visit vignette or S2 Healthcare Visitor visa”.

1.   V 2.2. A person applying for permission to stay as a Visitor must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form “Application to extend stay in the UK: FLR(IR)”.

1.   V 2.3. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Visitor must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any required fee must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality.

1.   V.2.3A. An application for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must be aged 18 or older on the date of application; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have a valid diplomatic passport which satisfactorily establishes the applicant’s identity and nationality.

1.   V 2.4. An application for entry clearance as a Visitor must be made while the applicant is outside the UK and to a post designated to accept such applications.

1.   V 2.5. An application for permission to stay as a Visitor must be made by a person: 
    1.   (a) in the UK; and
    2.   (b) with permission as a Standard Visitor or Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor.

1.   V 2.6. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a Visitor may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as UK Visitors. It requires online application, payment of fees, biometrics, and valid ID documents, with specific conditions for Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitors (must be 18+ and hold a diplomatic passport).

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for all Visitors

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for all Visitors

1.   V 3.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   V 3.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: All Visitor applicants must meet suitability criteria, meaning they must not breach immigration laws (unless exceptions apply), be on immigration bail, or be refused under Part Suitability. The applicant's lawful conduct and status are critical conditions for approval.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirements for Visitors

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirements for Visitors

1.   V 4.1. The decision maker must be satisfied that the applicant (unless they are applying for entry clearance or permission to enter as a Transit Visitor) meets all of the eligibility requirements in V 4.2. to V 4.6. and that they meet the specified additional eligibility requirements where the applicant: 
    1.   (a) is a child at the date of application, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 5.1. and V 5.2; or
    2.   (b) is coming to the UK under the Approved Destination Status Agreement, they must also meet the requirements at V 6.1; or
    3.   (c) is coming to the UK to receive private medical treatment, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 7.1. to V 7.3; or
    4.   (d) is coming to the UK as an organ donor, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 8.1. to V 8.4; or
    5.   (e) is coming to the UK to study as a Visitor, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 9.1. to V 9.5; or
    6.   (f) is an academic seeking a 12-month entry clearance, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 10.1; or
    7.   (g) is coming to the UK to undertake work related training, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 11.1. to V 11.3; or
    8.   (h) is coming to the UK to marry or form a civil partnership, or give notice of intention to marry or form a civil partnership, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 12.1. and V 12.2; or
    9.   (i) is coming to the UK to undertake permitted paid engagements, they must also meet the additional requirements in V 13.1. to V 13.3; or
    10.   (j) is applying for permission to stay as a Visitor, they must also meet the additional requirements at V 15.1. to V 15.4; or
    11.   (k) is applying for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement visitor, they must also meet the additional requirements at V15A.1. to V15A.4.
chunks.summary: Visitors must meet general eligibility criteria and any additional specific requirements based on their purpose, such as study, medical treatment, or marriage; exceptions apply for transit or entry clearance applicants.

metadata.section_title: Genuine visitor requirement

chunks.text:
### Genuine visitor requirement

1.   V 4.2. The applicant must satisfy the decision maker that they are a genuine visitor, which means the applicant: 
    1.   (a) will leave the UK at the end of their visit; and
    2.   (b) will not live in the UK for extended periods through frequent or successive visits, or make the UK their main home; and
    3.   (c) is genuinely seeking entry or stay for a purpose that is permitted under the Visitor route as set out in Appendix Visitor: Permitted Activities and at V 13.3; and
    4.   (d) will not undertake any of the prohibited activities set out in V 4.4. to V 4.6; and
    5.   (e) must have sufficient funds to cover all reasonable costs in relation to their visit without working or accessing public funds, including the cost of the return or onward journey, any costs relating to their dependants, and the cost of planned activities such as private medical treatment. The applicant must show that any funds they rely upon are held in a financial institution permitted under FIN 2.1 in Appendix Finance.

1.   V 4.3. In assessing whether an applicant has sufficient funds under V 4.2.(e), the applicant’s travel, maintenance and accommodation may be provided by a third party only if that third party: 
    1.   (a) has a genuine professional or personal relationship with the applicant; and
    2.   (b) is not, or will not be, in breach of immigration laws at the time of the decision or the applicant’s entry to the UK as a Visitor; and
    3.   (c) can and will provide support to the applicant for the intended duration of the applicant’s stay as a Visitor.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to visitors seeking entry to the UK. Applicants must demonstrate they are genuine visitors who will leave at the visit’s end, not live in the UK long-term, and intend to undertake permitted activities without engaging in prohibited ones. They must also prove sufficient funds, which can be provided by a third party only if a genuine relationship exists and laws are not breached.

metadata.section_title: Prohibited activities for Visitors

chunks.text:
### Prohibited activities and payment requirements for Visitors

1.   V 4.4. The Visitor must not intend to: 
    1.   (a) work in the UK, which includes: 
        1.   (i) taking employment in the UK; and
        2.   (ii) doing work for an organisation or business in the UK; and
        3.   (iii) establishing or running a business as a self-employed person; and
        4.   (iv) doing a work placement or internship; and
        5.   (v) direct selling to the public; and
        6.   (vi) providing goods and services,

    2.   unless expressly allowed by the permitted activities in Appendix Visitor: Permitted Activities or Appendix Visitor: Permit Free Festival List; or
    3.   (b) study in the UK, except as permitted by Appendix Visitor: Permitted Activities (and provided they meet the relevant additional requirements for study); or
    4.   (c) access medical treatment, other than private medical treatment or to donate an organ (for either of these activities they must meet the relevant additional eligibility requirements); or
    5.   (d) get married or form a civil partnership, or give notice of intention to marry or form a civil partnership, unless they are applying for entry clearance as a Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor or are a relevant national as defined in section 62 of the Immigration Act 2014.

1.   V 4.5. Permitted activities must not amount to the Visitor undertaking employment, or doing work which amounts to them filling a role or providing short-term cover for a role within a UK based organisation and where the Visitor is already paid and employed outside of the UK they must remain so.

1.   V 4.6. The Visitor must not receive payment from a UK source for any activities undertaken in the UK, except for the following: 
    1.   (a) reasonable expenses to cover the cost of their travel and subsistence, including fees for directors attending board-level meetings; or
    2.   (b) international drivers or Seafarers undertaking activities permitted under PA 9.2 to PA 9.4; or
    3.   (c) prize money; or
    4.   (d) billing a UK client for their time in the UK, where the Visitor’s overseas employer is contracted to provide services to a UK company, and the majority of the contract work is carried out overseas (payment must be lower than the amount of the Visitor’s salary); or
    5.   (e) multi-national companies who, for administrative reasons, handle payment of their employees’ salaries from the UK; or
    6.   (f) paid performances at a permit free festival as listed in Appendix Visitor: Permit Free Festival List, where the Visitor is an artist, entertainer or musician; or
    7.   (g) the permitted paid engagements listed in V 13.3, providing the requirements in V 13.1 and V 13.2 are met.
chunks.summary: Visitors must not work, study (unless permitted), access medical treatment (except privately or for organ donation), or marry/civil partner without specific permission. Exceptions apply only for activities explicitly allowed under designated permitted activities or visa types. Critical conditions include adherence to these restrictions to remain within legal entry purposes.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for children

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for children

1.   V 5.1. Adequate arrangements must have been made for a child’s travel to, reception and care in the UK.

1.   V 5.2. If the child is not travelling with a parent or legal guardian, based in their home country or country of ordinary residence, who is responsible for their care, that parent or legal guardian must consent to the child’s travel to, reception and care in the UK and, where requested, this consent must be given in writing.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children applying for a UK visitor visa. It requires that adequate travel, reception, and care arrangements are in place, with parental or guardian consent if not traveling with a responsible adult or guardian.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors under the Approved Destination Status Agreement

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors under the Approved Destination Status Agreement

1.   V 6.1. A person applying for entry clearance as a Visitor under the Approved Destination Status Agreement must: 
    1.   (a) be a national of the People’s Republic of China; and
    2.   (b) intend to enter, leave and travel within the UK as a member of a tourist group under the Approved Destination Status Agreement.
chunks.summary: Visitors from China applying under the Approved Destination Status must be Chinese nationals and intend to travel within the UK as part of a tourist group under the agreement. This eligibility specifically applies to those participating in approved tourism arrangements.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to receive private medical treatment

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to receive private medical treatment

1.   V 7.1. If the applicant is suffering from a communicable disease they must have satisfied the medical inspector that they are not a danger to public health.

1.   V 7.2. The applicant must have arranged their private medical treatment before they travel to the UK, and must provide either:
2.   (a) a letter from their doctor or consultant in the UK detailing: 
    1.   (i) the medical condition requiring consultation or treatment; and
    2.   (ii) the estimated costs and likely duration of any treatment, which must be of a finite duration; and
    3.   (iii) where the consultation or treatment will take place; or

3.   (b) if the applicant intends to receive NHS treatment under a reciprocal healthcare arrangement between the UK and another country, an authorisation form issued by the government of that country.

1.   V 7.3. If the applicant is applying for an 11-month entry clearance for the purposes of private medical treatment they must also: 
    1.   (a) provide either: 
        1.   (i) evidence from their doctor or consultant in the UK that the proposed treatment is likely to exceed 6 months, but not more than 11 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant intends to receive NHS treatment under a reciprocal healthcare arrangement between the UK and another country, an authorisation form issued by the government of that country which clearly states that the proposed treatment is likely to exceed 6 months, but not more than 11 months; and

    2.   (b) if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate, confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Visitors coming for private medical treatment must ensure they are not a public health risk if infectious, and must have pre-arranged treatment with supporting UK medical details or reciprocal healthcare authorisation. For stays up to 11 months, they must also demonstrate that treatment may last over six months but not exceeding 11 months.

    2.   (ii) the estimated costs and likely duration of any treatment, which must be of a finite duration; and
    3.   (iii) where the consultation or treatment will take place; or

3.   (b) if the applicant intends to receive NHS treatment under a reciprocal healthcare arrangement between the UK and another country, an authorisation form issued by the government of that country.

1.   V 7.3. If the applicant is applying for an 11-month entry clearance for the purposes of private medical treatment they must also: 
    1.   (a) provide either: 
        1.   (i) evidence from their doctor or consultant in the UK that the proposed treatment is likely to exceed 6 months, but not more than 11 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant intends to receive NHS treatment under a reciprocal healthcare arrangement between the UK and another country, an authorisation form issued by the government of that country which clearly states that the proposed treatment is likely to exceed 6 months, but not more than 11 months; and

    2.   (b) if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate, confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to donate an organ

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to donate an organ

1.   V 8.1. The applicant must satisfy the decision maker that they genuinely intend to donate an organ to, or be assessed as a potential organ donor for, an identified recipient in the UK with whom they have a genetic or close personal relationship.

1.   V 8.2. The applicant must provide written confirmation of medical tests to show that they are a donor match to the identified recipient, or that they are undergoing further tests to be assessed as a potential donor to the identified recipient.

1.   V 8.3. The applicant must provide a letter, dated no more than 3 months before the applicant’s intended date of arrival in the UK from either: 
    1.   (a) the lead nurse or coordinator of the UK NHS Trust’s Living Donor Kidney Transplant team; or
    2.   (b) a UK registered medical practitioner who holds an NHS consultant post or who appears in the Specialist Register of the General Medical Council;

2.   which confirms that the applicant meets the requirements in V 8.1. and V 8.2. and confirms when and where the planned organ transplant or medical tests will take place.

1.   V 8.4. The applicant must be able to show, if required to do so, that the identified recipient is lawfully present in the UK, or will be at the time of the planned organ transplant.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to visitors coming to the UK to donate an organ. They must demonstrate genuine intent, provide recent medical confirmation of donor-recipient matching, and obtain a supporting letter from UK medical authorities confirming eligibility and transplant details; exceptions include lawful presence of the recipient in the UK.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to study for up to six months

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK to study for up to six months

1.   V 9.1. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to study, they must have been accepted onto a course of study that is to be provided by an Accredited Institution that is not a State Funded School or Academy.

1.   V 9.2. The course of study referred to in V 9.1. must last no longer than six months unless the course is being undertaken from outside the UK as a Distance Learning Course.

1.   V 9.3. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK for up to six months to undertake electives relevant to a course of study abroad, they must: 
    1.   (a) be aged 16 or over; and
    2.   (b) be enrolled on a course of study abroad equivalent to at least degree level study in the UK; and
    3.   (c) be studying medicine, veterinary medicine and science, nursing, midwifery, or dentistry as their principal course of study; and
    4.   (d) have been accepted by a UK Higher Education Provider to undertake electives relevant to their course of study provided these are unpaid and involve no treatment of patients; and
    5.   (e) provide written confirmation from the UK Higher Education Provider.

1.   V 9.4. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to undertake research or be taught about research (research tuition) for up to six months: 
    1.   (a) they must be aged 16 or over; and
    2.   (b) they must be enrolled on a course of study abroad equivalent to at least degree level study in the UK; and
    3.   (c) they must have been accepted by a UK Higher Education Provider to undertake research or be taught about research (research tuition); and
    4.   (d) the overseas course provider must confirm that the research or research tuition is part of or relevant to the course of study that they are enrolled on overseas; and
    5.   (e) this must not amount to the Visitor being employed at the UK institution.

1.   V 9.5. The research or research tuition referred to in V 9.4. may be undertaken at a UK research institute, providing a formal partnership exists between the research institute and the UK Higher Education Provider for this purpose.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking to visit the UK for study up to six months must be accepted onto an accredited institution course (not state-funded), with courses lasting no more than six months unless via distance learning. Specific rules apply for electives and research, requiring age over 16, relevant enrollments, and, for electives, unpaid, non-patient treatment placements with UK provider confirmation.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for academics seeking to come to the UK for more than 6 months

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for academics seeking to come to the UK for more than 6 months

1.   V 10.1. An academic applying for a 12-month entry clearance must: 
    1.   (a) intend to undertake one (or more) of the following activities for up to 12 months: 
        1.   (i) take part in formal exchange arrangements with UK counterparts (including doctors); or
        2.   (ii) carry out research for their own purposes, if they are on sabbatical leave from their home institution; or
        3.   (iii) if they are an eminent senior doctor or dentist, take part in research, teaching or clinical practice, provided this does not amount to filling a permanent teaching post;

    2.   and
    3.   (b) be highly qualified within their own field of expertise; and
    4.   (c) currently be working in that field at an academic institution or institution of higher education overseas; and
    5.   (d) if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Academics seeking UK entry clearance for over 6 months must intend to engage in specific academic activities, be highly qualified, and currently work at a foreign higher education institution. They must also provide a tuberculosis screening certificate if applicable. These requirements apply to those aiming for up to 12 months of stay under defined research or teaching purposes.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK for work related training

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for Visitors coming to the UK for work related training

1.   V 11.1. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to undertake a clinical attachment or dental observer post as an overseas graduate from a medical, dental or nursing school, they must provide written confirmation of their offer to take up this post and confirm they have not previously undertaken this activity in the UK.

1.   V 11.2. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to take the Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board test, they must provide written confirmation of this from the General Medical Council.

1.   V 11.3. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to take the Objective Structured Clinical Examinations for overseas, they must provide written confirmation of this from the Nursing and Midwifery Council.
chunks.summary: Visitors coming to the UK for work-related training must provide specific confirmations: clinical attachments or dental observer posts require proof of offers and prior activity; taking the PLAB test needs GMC confirmation; OSCE exams require confirmation from the Nursing and Midwifery Council. Conditions include being an overseas graduate and adherence to specific training types.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK for purpose of marriage or civil partnership

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK for purpose of marriage or civil partnership

1.   V 12.1. The applicant must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

1.   V 12.2. The applicant must, within the period for which they are seeking permission as a Visitor: 
    1.   (a) intend to give notice of marriage or civil partnership in the UK; or
    2.   (b) intend to marry or form a civil partnership in the UK;

2.   which is not a sham marriage or civil partnership.
chunks.summary: Applicants aged 18 or over applying to visit the UK to marry or form a civil partnership must intend to do so within their permission period, ensuring the marriage or partnership is genuine and not sham.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK for Permitted Paid Engagements

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK for Permitted Paid Engagements

1.   V 13.1. Where the applicant is seeking to come to the UK to undertake a permitted paid engagement, they must be aged 18 or over when they enter the UK.

1.   V 13.2. The applicant must intend to do one (or more) of the permitted paid engagements set out in V 13.3. which must be: 
    1.   (a) arranged before the applicant travels to the UK; and
    2.   (b) declared as part of the application for entry clearance or , if asked, declared when seeking permission to enter the UK; and
    3.   (c) evidenced by a formal invitation, as required by V 13.3; and
    4.   (d) relate to the applicant’s area of expertise and occupation overseas.

1.   V 13.3. The following are permitted paid engagements: 
    1.   (a) an academic who is highly qualified within their field of expertise, coming to examine students and/or participate in or chair selection panels, and have been invited by a UK higher education institution, or a UK-based research or arts organisation as part of that institution or organisation’s quality assurance processes; and
    2.   (b) an expert coming to give lectures in their subject area, where they have been invited by a higher education institution, or a UK-based research or arts organisation, and this does not amount to filling a teaching position for the host organisation; and
    3.   (c) an overseas designated pilot examiner coming to assess UK-based pilots to ensure they meet the national aviation regulatory requirements of other countries, where they have been invited by an approved training organisation based in the UK that is regulated by the UK Civil Aviation Authority for that purpose; and
    4.   (d) a qualified lawyer coming to provide advocacy for a court or tribunal hearing, arbitration or other form of dispute resolution for legal proceedings within the UK, where they have been invited by a client; and
    5.   (e) a professional artist, entertainer, or musician coming to carry out an activity directly relating to their profession, where they have been invited by a creative (arts or entertainment) organisation, agent or broadcaster based in the UK; and
    6.   (f) a Professional Sportsperson coming to carry out an activity directly relating to their profession, where they have been invited by a sports organisation, agent, or broadcaster based in the UK; and
    7.   (g) a speaker coming to the UK to give a one-off or short series of talks and speeches, where they have been invited to a conference or other event.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to visitors aged 18 or over undertaking permitted paid engagements in the UK. They must have arranged and declared their engagements beforehand, with formal invitations, and their activities must align with their expertise and specific permitted categories such as academic examinations, lectures, or pilot assessments. Engagements must be pre-arranged, declared, evidenced, and relate to their professional expertise.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK to transit

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirement for Visitors coming to the UK to transit

1.   V 14.1. A visa national must hold entry clearance as a Standard Visitor, Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor or Transit Visitor, unless they meet the requirements for admission under Appendix Visitor: Transit Without Visa Scheme, in which case they may apply for permission to enter on arrival in the UK.

1.   V 14.2. An applicant applying for entry clearance or permission to enter as a Transit Visitor must satisfy the decision maker that they: 
    1.   (a) are genuinely in transit to another country outside the Common Travel Area, meaning the main purpose of their visit is to transit the UK (passing through immigration control) and that the applicant is taking a reasonable transit route; and
    2.   (b) will not access public funds or medical treatment, work or study in the UK; and
    3.   (c) genuinely intend and are able to leave the UK within 48 hours after their arrival; and
    4.   (d) are assured entry to their country of destination and any other countries they are transiting on their way there.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to visa nationals seeking UK transit entry. They must hold valid entry clearance or meet the Transit Without Visa scheme, and demonstrate they are genuinely transiting within 48 hours, will not access public funds or work, and have assured entry to their destination. Passengers must take a reasonable route; exceptions allow application for permission on arrival.

metadata.section_title: Additional eligibility requirements for permission to stay as a Visitor

chunks.text:
### Additional eligibility requirements for permission to stay as a Visitor

1.   V 15.1. Where the applicant is applying for permission to stay as a Visitor for the purpose of receiving private medical treatment they must also: 
    1.   (a) satisfy the decision maker that the costs of any medical treatment already received have been met; and
    2.   (b) provide either: 
        1.   (i) a letter from a registered medical practitioner, at a private practice or NHS hospital, who holds an NHS consultant post or who appears in the Specialist Register of the General Medical Council, detailing the medical condition requiring further treatment; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant intends to continue to receive NHS treatment under a reciprocal healthcare arrangement between the UK and another country, an authorisation form issued by the government of that country which authorises further treatment.

1.   V 15.2. Where the applicant applying for permission to stay is an academic (or the accompanying partner or child of such an academic) they must: 
    1.   (a) continue to intend to: 
        1.   (i) take part in formal exchange arrangements with UK counterparts (including doctors); or
        2.   (ii) carry out research for their own purposes, if they are on sabbatical leave from their home institution; or
        3.   (iii) if they are an eminent senior doctor or dentist, take part in research, teaching or clinical practice, provided this does not amount to filling a permanent teaching post; and

    2.   (b) be highly qualified within their own field of expertise; and
    3.   (c) have been working in that field at an academic institution or institution of higher education overseas prior to their arrival in the UK.

1.   V 15.3. Where the applicant is applying for permission to stay as a Visitor to resit the Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board Test, they must provide written confirmation of this from the General Medical Council.

1.   V 15.4. Where the applicant is applying for permission to stay as a Visitor and they are an overseas graduate of a medical, dental or nursing school intending to undertake an unpaid clinical attachment or dental observer post, they must have been successful in the Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board test.

Applicants must demonstrate funds cover existing treatment costs and provide relevant medical or healthcare authorization, or confirm ongoing research or academic activities. Key conditions include meeting specific documentation and eligibility criteria, with exceptions for certain research and senior medical roles.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirement for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor:

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirement for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor:

V 15A.1. The decision maker must be satisfied that the Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor’s application is supported by a Note Verbale issued by the government of their nationality.

1.   V 15A.2. The Note Verbale must be issued by the government of the applicant’s country of nationality and include: 
    1.   (a) the applicant’s name, date of birth and passport number; and
    2.   (b) confirmation that the application is supported by the government of their nationality.

V 15A.3. The Note Verbale must have been issued on or prior to the application date and the government of their nationality must not have withdrawn the Note Verbale or support for the application by issuing a new Note Verbale.

1.   V 15A.4. The applicant must travel on or after 11 March 2025 and be: 
    1.   (a) national of the People’s Republic of China who holds a diplomatic passport issued by the People’s Republic of China; or
    2.   (b) a national of Indonesia who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Indonesia; or
    3.   (c) a national of South Africa who holds a diplomatic passport issued by South Africa; or
    4.   (d) a national of Turkey who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Turkey; or
    5.   (e) national of Vietnam who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Vietnam.

Part: Immigration Rules Appendix V: Visitor
Section ID: V 15A
Section: Eligibility requirement for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor:
Topic: eligibility

Summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking entry as Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitors. They must be supported by an official Note Verbale from their government, issued before the application date, confirming support and containing personal details. Additionally, travel must occur on or after 11 March 2025, and applicants must hold a diplomatic passport from specified countries (China, Indonesia, South Africa, Turkey, Vietnam).

### Eligibility requirement for entry clearance as a Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor:

V 15A.1. The decision maker must be satisfied that the Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor’s application is supported by a Note Verbale issued by the government of their nationality.

1.   V 15A.2. The Note Verbale must be issued by the government of the applicant’s country of nationality and include: 
    1.   (a) the applicant’s name, date of birth and passport number; and
    2.   (b) confirmation that the application is supported by the government of their nationality.

V 15A.3. The Note Verbale must have been issued on or prior to the application date and the government of their nationality must not have withdrawn the Note Verbale or support for the application by issuing a new Note Verbale.

1.   V 15A.4. The applicant must travel on or after 11 March 2025 and be: 
    1.   (a) national of the People’s Republic of China who holds a diplomatic passport issued by the People’s Republic of China; or
    2.   (b) a national of Indonesia who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Indonesia; or
    3.   (c) a national of South Africa who holds a diplomatic passport issued by South Africa; or
    4.   (d) a national of Turkey who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Turkey; or
    5.   (e) national of Vietnam who holds a diplomatic passport issued by Vietnam.

### Decision

1.   V 16.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability requirements are met, and that the relevant eligibility requirements for a Visitor are met, the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant for Visitors

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant for Visitors

1.   V 17.1. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) no work (which does not prohibit the permitted activities in Appendix Visitor: Permitted Activities or Appendix Visitor: Permit Free Festival List; and
    3.   (c) no study except where permitted by Appendix Visitor: Permitted Activities at PA 2. and PA 17.
    4.   (d) study or research as part of a permitted activity is subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.

1.   V 17.2. Entry clearance and permission to enter as a Visitor will be granted for the periods set out in the following table:

|  | Visitor type | Maximum initial length of stay in the UK |
| --- | --- |
| (a) | Standard Visitor | up to 6 months except: (i) a Visitor who is coming to the UK for private medical treatment may be granted entry clearance for up to 11 months; (ii) an academic (or the accompanying partner or child of such an academic), who is employed by an overseas institution and is carrying out the specific permitted activities at V 10.1 (a), may be granted entry clearance for up to 12 months; (iii) a Visitor under the Approved Destination Status Agreement may be granted entry clearance for up to 30 days. |
| (b) | Marriage / Civil Partnership Visitor | up to 6 months |
| (c) | Transit Visitor | up to 48 hours, except for permission to enter as a Transit Visitor under the Transit Without Visa Scheme which may be granted until 23:59 hours on the next day after the day the applicant arrived in the UK. |
| (d) | Diplomatic Visa Arrangement Visitor | up to 6 months. |

1.   V 17.3. Permission to stay will be granted for the following periods: 
    1.   (a) a Standard Visitor or a Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor, who was granted permission for less than 6 months may be granted permission to stay for a period which results in the total period they can remain in the UK (including both the original grant and the extension) not exceeding 6 months; and
    2.   (b) a Standard Visitor who is in the UK for private medical treatment may be granted permission to stay as a Visitor for a further 6 months, provided the purpose is for private medical treatment; and
    3.   (c) a Standard Visitor who is in the UK to undertake the activities in V 10.1 (a), or the accompanying partner or child of such a Standard Visitor, may be granted permission to stay for a period which results in the total period they can remain in the UK (including both the original grant and the extension) not exceeding 12 months; and
    4.   (d) a Standard Visitor may be granted permission to stay as a Visitor for up to 6 months in order to resit the Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board Test; and
    5.   (e) a Standard Visitor who is successful in the Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board Test may be granted permission to stay as a Visitor to undertake the activities in PA 10.1. (a) for a period which results in the total period they can remain in the UK (including both the original grant and the extension) not exceeding 18 months.
